MOTION OF CONFIDENCE


2.34 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move this motion of confidence in the Government,

    That this House expresses its confidence in the Government.

    The events of the past week have been so rapid and dramatic that it would take some time for everybody to grasp their full significance. On Monday, the 10th of July-ten days ago - at a forum at the University of Malaya especially organised for the occasion to discuss the basis of merger, an open collision took place between Mr Devan Nair, who represented the P.A.P., and Mr Woodhull, who represented Mr Lim Ching Siong and four others in the T.U.C. Mr Woodhull, Mr Devan Nair, Mr Lim Ching Siong, Mr Fong Swee Suan, the Deputy Prime Minister, myself and several other members of the Central Executive Committee of my Party were old comrades in the P.A.P. Now an open break has taken place when Mr Woodhull, a Political Secretary in the present Government, in the last week of the Anson by-election, openly attacked Mr Devan Nair, a former member of the P.A.P. and a P.A.P. stalwart.

    On Friday, the 14th of July - six days ago-eight Assemblymen of the P.A.P. came out supporting the Trade Union Six; and, in open breach of Party discipline and the rules of decency, created public confusion by demanding the P.A.P.'s disavowal of Mr Devan Nair.

    What was this all about? Their object in doing this was to make us lose the Anson by-election and the more heavily our candidate was defeated, the more it suited their plot. They have succeeded in making our candidate lose. 1,500 people abstained from voting in Anson, disillusioned by this Party dissension brought out into the open deliberately on the eve of Polling Day, and we lost to the present Member for Anson by 546 votes.

    What is it all about? The time has come to begin to explain frankly what is happening and why it is happening. After Hong Lim, when we were defeated badly, I felt that if the people desired

Column: 1665

it, there should be a reference back to the people. However, it was decided by a majority opinion of the Party that we should first fight Anson and then reconsider the position. At that time, Mr Lim Ching Siong and all his trade union friends strenuously opposed any talk of our resignation. Now, however, after losing Anson by a narrow majority, and because of this attempt by the Trade Union Six and eight Assemblymen - one of whom is a member of the Trade Union Six - to capture the Government and the Party, we are resolved not to abdicate our position in order that the Party and the Government does not pass into the hands of people who intend to use it for purposes for which the people did not vote the P.A.P. in. The present leadership of the Party was responsible for winning the last elections and getting the mandate of the people, and it is our duty not to give Mr Lim Ching Siong and his friends any opportunity to take over this Government in order to run it as a Communist front Government.

    What is it all about? Their first plan now, since they are unable to capture the Government, is to get me to resign in order that someone whom they believe they can manipulate could be elected Prime Minister. They hope in this way to force a compromise in the policy of the Government so that they can extend Communist influence in Singapore and prevent us from fulfilling our declared objective of independence through merger with the Federation with or without the Borneo territories in 1963. This move has now been frustrated by the unanimous decision of the Central Executive Committee to stand collectively together against any change. And this stand has been endorsed by a majority of P.A.P. Assemblymen.

    This motion is one of confidence and the motion will have to be carried as it stands without amendment, or the Government must resign and general elections follow. On a motion of confidence, any amendment is tantamount to a vote of no confidence.

    As for the hon. Members on the other side of the House, may I say, on behalf of my colleagues and I, that if they want general elections then they can vote against the Government.

Column: 1666



    This extraordinary session has become necessary because of the sudden turn of events of the last few weeks. Eight Assemblymen on the P.A.P. side have openly defied the Party leadership. Demands for my resignation as Prime Minister have been made and it is now necessary that the House should clearly give us a mandate to carry on.

    You will recall, Mr Speaker, Sir, that when we last met on 14th June, 1961, the House was adjourned sine die, the reason being that we expected to prorogue the session and re-convene again at the end of October after you have returned from a C.P.A. conference in London. I understand you will be leaving Singapore in September and returning in mid-October. Therefore, before this House goes into recess, we must make it clear to the people that we have the mandate of the Assembly to carry on as the Government.

    By this stand we know that we shall face a fresh offensive which will be mounted maybe on labour and industrial sections and on many other fronts. Therefore, it was necessary that I should have a clear mandate from the Central Executive Committee and the P.A.P. Assemblymen who have to go into battle with us. This mandate I have been given by the Party, and I now formally ask it of the Assembly.

    It is my duty to tell the House of the trials and tribulations which lie ahead and of the many unpleasant things which may have to be done in order to maintain the economy of this island and the people's welfare.

    The time has come also for the unvarnished truth to be told. For two years, the British Government has tried to manipulate the P.A.P. into a position where we will become the successor to what was called the Lim Yew Hock Government, where the Communist Party will be attacked not by British imperialism, which is the supreme power in Singapore, but by us, the locally elected Government with limited powers. To achieve this end, every blandishment and argument has been put forward, and every device and seductive manoeuvre practised.

Column: 1667



    After two years, the British have decided that the P.A.P. is impervious probably to such blandishment and perhaps they have decided that we may be men who are not influenced by personal considerations of wishing to stay in power. We have stated that we are prepared to lay down our office at any time at the behest of the people and we are not going to be manipulated by any power.

    The big scheme we have only been able to piece together after the Anson by-election. The plot, counter-plot and sub-plots that have been going on would make an Oppenheim thriller read like a simple comic strip cartoon. The diplomacy, skill and cunning of some 300 years of the building and running of the British Empire, and in the manipulation of men and their motivations have in great part led to this curious position, daily going curiouser and curiouser.

    The British, as I see it, had two objectives. The first objective was to engineer a collision between the non-Communist Left in the P.A.P. and the Communist Left leadership in the unions. Their second objective is to ensure that the Borneo territories are put into a position where they will come together immediately in a federation under British tutelage, but in a state of readiness if the international situation turns delicate to be transferred to a nationalist government of "Greater Malaysia".

    I congratulate the planners of this scheme for having succeeded thus far. Day by day, on the basis of British blandishments, manoeuvres, hints and gestures, all parties - the Communists, the P.A.P., the Federation and the leaders of the Borneo territories - have all been putting in stakes on the poker table, and they are mounting. To the pro-Communists in Singapore, the British say, have said, and are saying, that they are liberal and democratic, and that if they have released men from prison to be Prime Ministers, and only recently have done so again in Nyasaland, then why should they want to

Column: 1668

keep detainees in gaol? It is darkly hinted that it is the wicked Singapore Government that wanted to keep them in gaol.

    These insinuations started slowly. After the Hong Lim by-election, they were intensified. The British were unhappy that in Hong Lim the Communist Left rallied to the P.A.P. united front. I emphasise the P.A.P. united front, and not the Communist united front. So some plan had to be devised to ensure that the P.A.P. would come into collision with the Communist Left. Dinner parties, cocktails and luncheons led to friendly fraternisation between the British Lion and Messrs. Lim Ching Siong, Woodhull and Company. The pro-Communists were led to believe that the P.A.P. were wicked obstructionists, and that the British, wise and statesmanlike people were prepared even to envisage a new "Left" government emerging in Singapore even more Left than the P.A.P., provided their military bases were not touched. What has happened is that the British have become their own agents-provocateur. And how well they have succeeded! Quietly and insidiously they have instigated the pro-Communists to attempt the capture of both the P.A.P. Government and the Party. Young and inexperienced revolutionaries were so taken in that, in a crisis, Lim Ching Siong, Woodhull and Fong Swee Suan looked up the U.K. Commissioner for consultations last Tuesday, the 18th, at Eden Hall, the home of the British imperialists' representative. Sir, we felt that something curious was going on and we therefore kept the residence of the U.K. Commissioner under observation. Lo and behold! The great anti-colonialists and revolutionaries turned up for secret consultations with the British Lion. I am now convinced, Sir, that some funny things are happening when in a serious crisis this revolutionary trio, instead of getting in touch with the P.A.P., got into consultation with the U.K. Commissioner at Eden Hall. I therefore suggest that, having led the pro-Communists into believing that a non-Communist Government was no

Column: 1669

longer necessary and that a pro-Communist Government was possible, obviously these men were going to try and capture the P.A.P. and the Government. And the British may also have hoped that under attack and threat of capture, the P.A.P. would fight back and finally suppress the Communists, something they have so far failed in persuading the P.A.P. to do.

    Meanwhile, to the P.A.P., the British had suggested that we should take firm action against the mounting subversion. In fact, a plan was to have been drawn up which would have culminated in an act leading to open collision with the Communists in which the P.A.P. either remained in office, and so became committed forever to defend British colonialism, or resigned, in which case a non-Communist Government not amenable to British pressure would have been got rid off.

    Meanwhile, the Federation began to believe that they could get the Borneo territories, together with Singapore, merged into a larger federation. The Tunku came down to Singapore on 27th May, a week before National Day, and announced to a group of foreign correspondents that he recognised that there must be closer political and economic ties between the Federation of Malaya, Singapore and the three Borneo territories. I responded on the 3rd of June, National Day, that on principle we welcomed the Tunku's plan for a larger federation, if thereby merger between Singapore and the Federation was made easier.

    The Communists, on the other hand, immediately propounded that there was no need for independence through merger, and that the next step should be to abolish the Internal Security Council in order that there would be expansion at all levels of human activity on behalf of the Communist cause.

    Six trade unionists came out with statements openly supporting the Communist line on the 2nd of June. 42 trade unions also supported this C.P. line and literally put their rubber stamps on the statement to this effect without convening any meetings or consulting the rank and file. On the 9th of June, the P.A.P.

Column: 1670

Chairman, the Leader of the House, announced that the Government would demand complete independence through merger with the Federation, or merger with a larger federation when Constitutional talks reopen in 1963. The P.A.P. which was not amenable to manipulation by the British, is not going to be manipulated by the Communists.

    We took our stand and the battle then began. Three days after the 9th of June, the Trade Union Six demanded immediate release of the detainees, implementation of the reunification of trade unions, granting of citizenship rights to all those loyal to the anti-colonial struggle, Communists or non-Communists, and more freedom of speech, Press, assembly and organisation for the advancement of the anti-colonial struggle.

    Meanwhile, two Governors and one High Commissioner flew in from Borneo to add impetus and mystery to the fast developing plot. All these events incidentally lent credence to the false rumours that the P.A.P. had sold out Singapore to an imperialist plot. The U.K. Commissioner left for London; the Tunku and the Yang di-Pertuan Agong of the Federation went to Brunei. Everyone started his own analysis and adopted his own counter measures. The Member for Anson said this was all for the purpose of the Anson by-election. But the Communist Left believed differently and decided that this was an evil conspiracy to which the P.A.P. was a party. They mounted the offensive and intensified their campaign. The Trade Union Six openly attacked the P.A.P.; three Political Secretaries in receipt of Government remuneration flagrantly flouted all the rules of decency and attacked the Government they had promised to serve. 43 trade unions came out against merger supporting the Trade Union Six to make the P.A.P. lose in Anson. Finally, when in spite of everything the P.A.P. looked like winning, they engineered the betrayal of the Party by eight Assemblymen issuing a statement of discord on the eve of polls. These people had been duped into believing that the P.A.P. had sold out the rights of the people of Singapore.

Column: 1671



    Sir, it will take some time for me to tell you the story right from the beginning, and the story may have to be continued to be told, over a period of time. But I feel the people must know the truth in order that when the mandate is returned to them they can make their choice in full knowledge of the facts. And the choice will be - do you want your future to be a Singapore merged with the Federation of Malaya, or do you want to follow people who ask first for the abolition of the Internal Security Council, as a first step to an independent Communist Singapore? We saw these problems looming over the horizon even whilst the Hong Lim by-election was on, and I stressed over and over again why the P.A.P. does not stand for an independent Singapore and why our future must lie with the Federation.

    Mr Lim Ching Siong and his friends took fright and alarm when rapid developments began regarding merger. They were alarmed because merger is no longer a mirage over the horizon but a reality which will take place in 1963. Two Governors and one High Commissioner arrived from Borneo to discuss matters with Lord Selkirk. Lord Selkirk returned to London to discuss matters with his Government in London. The Tunku and the Agong went to Brunei, and the Tunku went on to Sarawak. The Tunku made a broadcast on the 4th of July announcing that he would take Brunei in as a State of the Federation, together with North Borneo and Sarawak. On the 11th of July at a Rotary dinner, the Tunku said he would hold talks with Singapore as to how Singapore should come in.

    Why do they oppose this merger? Why do they want to capture the Government and the Party to prevent this when for years they have always endorsed and supported the P.A.P. plan of independence through merger? Mr Lim Ching Siong, Mr Woodhull, Mr Fong came out from prison because we had won the elections and had demanded their release as a condition precedent before we assumed office. Although we knew that politically our opinions differed on important points of

Column: 1672

ideology from some of them, we were openly comrades in a united front and we did not betray them. But they, on the other hand, in the middle of a by-election which was crucial to the Government, and for the purpose of giving the P.A.P. a mandate for merger, for their own reasons, betrayed us openly at Anson, caused dissension in the Party ranks and confusion in the minds of the people.

    Meanwhile, the battle lines have already been drawn and forces drawn up on each side. A strange twist of events has taken place in Borneo. The people of Sarawak, it appears, do not want merger as a State with the Federation as the Tunku suggested. Neither, it appears, do the people of North Borneo in which no single political party yet exists. The British Governors talked of support for "Greater Malaysia" but only as a long-term plan. The Tunku was angered at this turn of events, and now openly attacked British colonialism which has put a stumbling block in the plan for merger of a larger federation. And ten Malayan officers were being intimidated and chased out of Brunei because it is believed and said that British police officers were dilatory in protecting the physical safety of the Malayan officers.

    Meanwhile, because "Greater Malaysia" had been presented to the people of Brunei, Sarawak and North Borneo as a Federation colonising effort, the three territories have for the first time in history come together voluntarily on the British plan of a Borneo federation. I congratulate the men who charted this course of events if, in fact, all these were intended. The British are now getting the three Borneo territories together for the first time into a federation, after they have failed so far in the past.

    Of course, the British supported the Tunku's plan for "Greater Malaysia" on principle, but they had always said that the Borneo territories must form a federation first before they merge with Malaya. As far as the Borneo territories are concerned, therefore, the British have got everyone well and happy, except probably the ten anxious Malayan officers in Brunei.

Column: 1673



    Meanwhile in Singapore they have succeeded in beguiling the pro-C.P. elements into believing that the P.A.P. had sold them out and encouraging them to openly attack and betray the P.A.P. in Anson by suggesting that there could be a government even more Left than the P.A.P. The British were happy, for they thought that after this collision the P.A.P. would have to take strong measures to ensure its survival.

    Sir, day by day the chips on the poker table are mounting. The game as has been played has gone so far now that no side can afford to back out, and some time in the near future all cards will be called and seen. Whoever is bluffing will lose bitterly.

    I now say on behalf of my colleagues and my Party that we are not going to fit in with the scheme to beat up the C.P. for the benefit of British colonialism. If we get no independence through merger, we will leave the British with the predicament of having to deal with the Communists themselves, even in an elected government.

    The Communists, on the other hand, have mounted their offensive in order to capture the P.A.P. Party and the P.A.P. Government. Needless to say, we shall resist them to prevent this from ever happening. We advise them not to try it and not to provoke us into unnecessary collision. If they want to win and take over power in Singapore, they may try to do so in the next general elections. We, on the other hand, must let the people know the truth - plain, simple, unvarnished - so that all will realise the hazardous course they will travel with these men.

    Our battle with the Communists must be won by argument and in the hearts and minds of the people. We will prove that the democratic socialist forces in Singapore are honest and sincere to the people, and have not sold out and will not sell out their rights to anybody. It will also be shown that the Communists have not only been duped by the British but duped to the extent that they betrayed their P.A.P. comrades in the nationalist Left united front.

Column: 1674



    I say the battle for men's minds cannot be won by simple smearing of a man being either anti-Communist, reactionary, wavering bourgeoisie, Social Democrat or Communist. As I said, the battle for men's minds cannot be won by simple labelling. Not all those who oppose the British are nationalists. Some anti-colonialists are nationalists and some are Communists.

    We also see this distinction that not all who oppose the P.A.P. are Communists; some are Communists, some reactionaries, some opportunists and some merely confused.

    Therefore, in this battle for ideas, it is necessary that we should call a spade a spade and put across truthfully the respective position of everyone. Our purpose is to build a movement for a united, independent, democratic, non-Communist Malaya. Our business is to strengthen the forces that help to create this united Malaya. In the past the Communists may have for their own reasons assisted us in this task. If so, they did it in the full knowledge that we are non-Communist, and not Communist.

    We are firmly convinced that the survival of the P.A.P. depends on a strong adherence to this line of non-Communism to prevent perversion of our Party, either by the British getting the P.A.P. into openly repressing the Communists, or by the Communists in making the P.A.P. the vehicle of their Communist line.

    As the game has been played so far, beyond any doubt the really able and skilful player has been the British. Even we, Mr Speaker, Sir, were at first puzzled by this strange development of events. On the one hand, we were asked to be tough and to take firm action. On the other hand, the British lion was asking the revolutionary Messrs. Lim and Woodhull & Co, to dinner and telling them that all the detainees can be let out, or suggesting to them that that could be so. And then their fellow-travelling friends come and tell us that they, the revolutionaries, have a first-class pipe-line with the U.K. Commission and are convinced that all that the

Column: 1675

British wanted in Singapore were their bases and quiet, peace and tranquillity, and even if a Communist government can be popularly elected, all would be well.

    For all sides the events of the last two months have been irrevocable ones. Such conflicts as have appeared between the pro-C.P. elements and the P.A.P. cannot just be laughed off and forgotten. The British are still hoping that we will come into open collision and that we will use draconian methods of suppression to establish our position. But as I have explained, Sir, we are completely unmoved by considerations of staying in office, pomp or power, for these were not the considerations that made us seek office in 1959. We can, therefore, afford to ignore these blandishments and present to the British the dragon's teeth that they have been sowing. But we shall fight to prevent the Government and the Party from capture.

    In many ways the events of the last two months bear resemblance to the crisis in the P.A.P. in 1957. There again the pro-Communist Left, whom we had called Left-Wing adventurers, miscalculated their position and tried to capture the P.A.P. and force us to follow their line. Very prudently we calculated differently and abstained from office, thereby saving the P.A.P. and ourselves a great deal of unnecessary trouble. As a result, we were able to survive, grow to greater strength and later succeed in the last General Elections and were able thereby to rescue Mr Lim, Mr Woodhull and six others from prison, before we assumed power.

    Now again in 1961, as in 1957, it is believed that the P.A.P. can be captured by Communists and used for Communist policies with impunity. Some of the lesser souls in our Party have decided to take the easy way out - this shortcut to peace in our time and popularity in our time. Little do they realise that this short-cut can only lead to peace only for a time and popularity only for a time.

    We have decided to stay and not abdicate to prevent this criminal folly from being perpetrated on the P.A.P. for

Column: 1676

the second time. I only hope these gamblers will not have to pay too high and bitter a price when the cards are opened.

    We ask these gentlemen of the Communist Left to stop and ponder on the adventure they are about to embark on. We the P.A.P. have never betrayed them. Although we never agreed with their ideological position, yet because we were in one anti-colonial front and they landed in gaol, the non-Communists in the P.A.P. carried on, won the General Elections in 1959, and secured their release. We were able to do this only because we were wise enough not to fall into a trap in 1957 when some Left-wing adventurers tried to capture the Party. On the other hand, the pro-Communists have been duped by the British. Having wined and dined with the lion, they are convinced that the lion will not eat them. It is our intention that as long as the constitutional position remains as it is, and no riots and no violence take place requiring the intervention of British troops and British generals, the P.A.P. will allow them full opportunities for free and open debate, leading if necessary to a victory for them in the next election. It is for them to decide what course they are to embark upon.

    On the question of the detainees arrested by the previous Government and still in detention, my colleague, the Leader of the House, will be making a statement. We intend to get this irrelevant issue out of the political scene by implementing the memorandum which we submitted to the Internal Security Council in August 1959, for the continued releases in batches of all the detainees, arrested in two purges in 1956 and 1957 in which the P.A.P. was involved. As a result of the turn of events, we are convinced that it is in the interest of the country to get this issue out of the way, so that the real issue, merger, is not clouded over.

    On merger, let me repeat what the Party Chairman has said - that we stand for merger in 1963, independence through merger either direct with the Federation alone or together with the three Borneo States on the terms that there should be local autonomy on education and labour. There have been no details agreed upon; there have been no

Column: 1677

secret deals. I hope at a convenient time to discuss these matters with the Tunku on the basis for merger. When the terms and conditions are formulated, it is our intention not only to get this House to support it, but to get the whole country to endorse it.

    The moment of reckoning is fast approaching, partly by British design, partly by miscalculation and the gullibility of people who are supposed to be politically intelligent revolutionaries. The cards have been dealt out and gone out to them, and the game must come to its conclusion. Let me explain how we are going to play this game on our side. First, we intend to win the game not merely for the immediate present but for the long-term future. We are concerned not so much with immediately remaining in office, but in preparing the conditions for merger and presenting the issues to the people so that ultimately they can make the right choice on their future in full possession of all the facts. I stated in October 1959, in this House that as long as British power is supreme in Singapore, in any conflict between the armed Communists and the armed colonialists we must opt out. We have only limited arms - a Police Force, a small S.I.R. unit and a couple of riot squads. Violence and unrest which the Communists can mount on a scale that will require the intervention of British troops and the taking over of command by a British general must mean that we abdicate, or otherwise be labelled stooges of a colonial regime. It is therefore a matter for the Communist-Left to decide whether they want to get us out by bringing about this situation. If people are foolish enough to believe that they have got the freedom of the island to upset the base, or that they can have the freedom of the island provided they give a verbal guarantee about the base not being upset, then I wish them well.
